fields: Cells can communicate with one another in different ways. What are the three main ways?
Endocrine, paracrine, autocrine
{{c1::Paracrine}} and {{c1::autocrine}} signals have to be limited in their {{c2::diffusion}} to ensure that they are delivered to their proper target.

Mechanisms by which paracrine and autocrine signals have to be limited in their diffusion.
-Rapid {{c1::endocytosis}} of signal by neighboring cells.
-Desctruction by {{c1::extracellular}} enzymes
-Immobilization by {{c1::extracellular matrix}}.
Small molecules that serve as signaling molecules
Amino acids, gases (NO), ions (Ca2+), nucleotides
Receptors can be {{c1::ion channels}} and ligand binding causes a change in membrane potential. In this case, the only machinery needed for signal transcution is the {{c1::receptor}}.
Usually {{c1::ligand}} binding to receptor causes the receptor to associate with an {{c2::effector}} molecule to initiate a cellular response.
T/F Cells only respond to signals for which they have receptors or signaling components.
T
What are the five types of receptors

ligand-gated ion receptors
G protein coupled receptors
Catalytic receptors
Nuclear receptors.
{{c2::ligand-gated}} ion channel receptors are {{c1::integral}} membrane proteins
{{c1::Ligand-gated}} ion channel receptors are also hybrid {{c2::receptors/channels}} that are involved in {{c3::signaling}} between electrically excitable cells
{{c1::ligand gated}} ion channels transduce a {{c2::chemical}} signal into an {{c2::electrical}} signal
{{c1::Ligand gated}} ion channels are a {{c2::multisubunit}} membrane spanning receptors
{{c1::Signaling molecules}} control the openining and closing of ion channels by {{c2::binding}} to a site on the receptor
{{c2::Ionotropic receptors}} is another name for a {{c1::ligand gated ion channel}}
Ionotropic receptors for {{c2::acetylcholine}}, {{c2::serotonin}}, and {{c2::GABA}} are good examples of ligand gated ion channels
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} are integral plasma membrane proteins
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} work through an {{c2::intermediary}} to activate/inactivate a separate membrane associated enzyme or channel
The intermediary in a G protein-coupled receptors is {{c1::GTP}}
G protein-coupled receptors constitue the largest family of receptors on the {{c1::cell surface}}
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} mediate a cellular response to a diverse array of {{c2::signaling}} molecules (hormones, neurotransmitters, odorants etc)
Despite the {{c1::chemical}} diversity of their ligands, most {{c2::receptors}} have a similar structure
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} have {{c2::seven}} membrane-spanning alpha-helical segments
A {{c1::ligand binds}} onto G protein-coupled receptors on the extracellular {{c2::N terminus}} that is glycosylated
a {{c2::G protein-coupled receptor}} has a large cytoplasmic loope that has {{c3::hydrophilic}} amino acids between helices {{c1::5 and 6}}
G proteins are a member of the {{c1::GTP-binding protein}} family
G proteins are {{c1::heterotrimers}} that exist in many combinations of different {{c2::alpha, beta, & gamma}} subunits

The GTP-binding protein family includes:
1) {{c2::heterotrimeric}} G proteins that bind to {{c3::G-protein}} coupled receptors
2) small GTP-binding proteins, such as {{c1::RAS}}
Heterotrimeric and small G proteins can {{c1::hydrolyze}} {{c2::GTP}}
When heterotrimeric and small G proteins are hydrolyzed with GTP, they can switch between an {{c2::active}} {{c1::GTP-bound}} state and an {{c2::inactive}} {{c1::GDP-bound}} state
Heterotrimeric G proteins are composed of three subunits: {{c1::alpha, beta, and gamma}}
The {{c1::alpha}} subunit of heterotrimeric G proteins binds and hydrolyzes {{c2::GTP}}
Example is adenyly cyclase

The {{c1::beta/gamma}} complex of heterotrimeric G proteins, anchors the {{c2::trimeric}} complex to the membrane and functions in {{c3::signal transduction::type of transduction}} by interacting with certain effector molecules
G protein activation follows a {{c1::cycle}}

First step of the G protein activation cycle. Describe this step.

Hint: 1) This is in an inactive state. 2) Interaction between GDP and a specific subunit.

In the inactive state, heterotrimeric G-proteins have three subunits: alpha, beta, and gamma.

GDP occupies the guanine nucleotide-binding site of the alpha subunit.

Second step in the G protein activation cycle.
Describe this step.

After the ligand binds, the activated recptor interacts with the G protein to promote a conformational change. 

GDP is exchanged for GTP
Third step of the G protein activation cycle. Describe this step.
GDP-GTP exchange stimulates dissociation of the complex from the recptor
Fourth step of the G protein activation cycle. Describe this step.
Dissociation of the complex results in a disassembly of the trimer into a free alpha subunit and beta/gamma complex

Fifth step of the G protein activation cycle. 
Describe this step.

Free & active GTP-bound alpha subunit can now interact with downstream effectors (adenyly cylcase and phospholipases)

Beta/gamma complex can now activate ion channels or other effectors

Sixth step of the G protein activation cycle. 
Describe this step.

Alpha subunit terminates the signaling events by hydrolyzing GTP to GDP and inorganic phosphate

Results in an inactive alpha-GDP complex that dissociates from downstream effector and reassociates with beta/gamma subunit
{{c1::Second messenger}} systems {{c2::amplify}} signals and {{c3::integrate}} responses among cell type
Cells rapidly {{c1::produce or activate}} the second messenger and then {{c2::inactivates or degrades}} it
The involvement of {{c2::second messengers}} in catalytic cascades provides numerous opportunities to {{c1::amplify}} a signal
{{c1::Amplifying}} a signal usually involves the conversion of an {{c2::inactive}} species into an {{c2::active}} one
What are the six examples of second messengers?

- cAMP
- cGMP
- IP3
- DAG
- Arachidonic acid
- Ca2+
Coronary artery atherosclerosis causes angina pectoris (chest pain from low blood flow to heart muscle). How do you relieve this pain? What receptor gets stimulated?

Nitric Oxide (NO) is important in treating Angina Pectoris 

Spontaneously break down nitroglycerin to NO. In smooth muscle, NO stimulates soluble guanylyl cyclase (GTP --> cGMP)
-cGMP concentration increases --> relaxes smooth muscles of peripheral arterioles --> vasodilation --> heart works less & relieves associated pain
What receptor + product is responsible for having an erection?

Alright so, males get visually stimulated and produce NO, goes into the smooth muscle, activates soluble guanine cyclase (GTP --> cGMP) --> ↓[Ca2+] --> smooth muscle relaxes --> vasodilation --> increases blood into penis --> erection
What enzyme reduces erection? So old people who wants an erection uses what drug?

PDE5 (phosphodiesterase-5) breaks down cGMP --> GMP
↓ [cGMP] = no erection :(

Sildenafil blocks PDE5 = ↑ [cGMP] :)
viagra: sildenafil citrate
This plasma membrane receptors have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity. So..can they phosphorylate themselves? And what are the factors that can bind to this kind of receptor?

Receptor tyrosine kinase
can phosphorylate themselves & other cellular proteins

Epidermal growth factor (EGF)
platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF)
vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)
insulin and insulin-related growth factor type 1 (IGF-1) 
fibroblast growth factor (FGF)
nerve growth factor (NGF) can all bind to receptors that possess intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity
How do you activate receptor tyrosine kinase complex?

Most RTKs are single-pass transmembrane proteins that contain a single intracellular kinase domain.

Ligand binding (ie. NGF) induces a conformational change in the receptor that helps form receptor dimers.
Dimerization allows the two cytoplasmic catalytic domains to phosphorylate each other ("autophosphorylation") and thereby activate the receptor complex.
Which receptor can undergo autophosphorylation?

Receptor tyrosine kinase

Dimerization allows the two cytoplasmic catalytic domains to phosphorylate each other ("autophosphorylation") and thereby activate the receptor complex.
what receptor creates phosphotyrosine motifs? What does this motif serve as?

Receptor tyrosine kinases dimerizes, autophosphorylates, and phosphorylates tyrosine residues on specific cytoplasmic protein. 

Resulting in phosphotyrosine motifs of receptor & other protein substrates:
-serves as high-affinity binding sites for intracellular signaling molecules.
-high-affinity binding sites for recruiting many cytoplasmic or membrane-associated proteins that has SH2 (Src homology 2), SH3 (Src homology 3), or PTB (phosphotyrosine-binding) domains
what common pathway do activated Receptor Tyrosine Kinases use to transduce their signal to cytosol & nucleus ..resulting in an <u>increase/decrease</u> of activity in what small GTP-binding protein?

Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase 

↑ in small GTP-binding protein RAS 


GRB2 (Growth factor Receptor-Bound protein 2)
SOS (Son Of Sevenless)
Mitogen Activated Protein Kinase

GRB2 (Growth factor Receptor-Bound protein 2)
SOS (Son Of Sevenless)
Do tyrosine kinase-associated receptors have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity?
No but can associate w/ nonreceptor tyrosine kinases
Tyrosine kinases-associated receptors have enzymatic activity?

No but JAK does. 

Tyrosine kinases of the Src family and Janus family (JAK or Janus kinases) associate noncovalently with the cytoplasmic domains of these receptors
Several cytokines use what receptor?

Tyrosine kinase-associated receptors

Receptors in this class include those for several cytokines, including IL-2, IL-3, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, leukemia inhibitory factor (LIF), granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF), and erythropoietin (EPO)

sorry the night is getting late and dont really know what it's saying.
Does tyrosine kinase-associated receptor phosphorylate itself when it's activated?

No

Ligand binding to these tyrosine kinase-associated receptors results in receptor dimerization and tyrosine kinase activity (JAK2).

Activated Kinase (JAK2)  phosphorylates tyrosines on itself + receptor
What is required for lymphocyte activation?
receptor tyrosine phosphatases
Is CD45 protein an example of receptor tyrosine associated receptor that is found on T + B lymphocytes?
NO. CD45 protein is a receptor tyrosine phosphatase found @ cell surface of T & B lymphocytes.
CD45 glycosylated extracellular domain functions as <u>tyrosine phosphatase activity</u> ?

NO
glycosylated extracellular domain: receptor for antibodies
cytoplasmic domain: tyrosine phosphatase activity
Nucelar receptors are found on the cell membrane?

No 
located in cytosol & nucleus
What receptors do steroid & thyroid hormones bind to to activate gene transcription?

Nuclear receptors

steroid & thyroid hormones enter cell & bind to nuclear receptor in cytoplasm or nucleus & bind to specific DNA sequences-called hormone response elements - in the regulatory region of responsive genes
What receptor links extracellular signals to gene tanscription?
Nuclear Receptors
